text:
What you hear in that skit is satire, not a faithful representation of the Bible. Yes, critics quote verses like Exodus 21:7 ‚ÄúAnd if a man sells his daughter as a servant‚Ä¶‚Äù‚Äîbut in the original ancient context, this wasn‚Äôt a free-for-all sale of human beings as property. It was a regulated servitude often tied to marriage contracts or provision in hard times, with strict protections, redemption rights, and limits on abuse by law (Exodus 21:7-11) ÔøΩ. Ancient Israel‚Äôs laws were often protective reforms compared to surrounding nations, not moral endorsements of exploitation ÔøΩ.
Taylor Bible Study
Gospel Doctrine
Also, the skit suggests Christians ‚Äúpick and choose‚Äù what parts of the Bible to follow‚Äîreal Christians don‚Äôt interpret Scripture by satire; we read context, covenant progression, and the teachings of Christ. Jesus never endorsed Old Testament civil laws for today, He fulfilled the Law and raised its ethical demands (Matthew 5:17). So mocking believers with selective quotes doesn‚Äôt address what the Bible actually teaches about love, justice, human dignity, and sacrifice.
If someone wants a fruitful conversation, look at the actual passages in context instead of relying on comedy sketches.
